tossups.answer: thyroid gland <RY, Biology> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

parts: Name this most famous Billy Strayhorn tune that features a Ray Nance trumpet solo that has been repeated verbatim by most performers. Its title is supposedly “the best way to get to Sugar Hill in Harlem.”
“Take the A Train” was the theme for this pianist’s big band. He also composed “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing).”
This man’s band was hired to replace the Duke Ellington Orchestra at the Cotton Club in 1930, and became a house band for the venue. His song “Minnie the Moocher” heavily features scat lyrics.

answers: Sarah Moore and Angelina Emily Grimké [accept Grimké sisters]
parts: Name this pair of abolitionists. These people also became early inspirations for the women’s suffrage movement after publishing “Letters on the Equality of the Sexes.”

Sarah Grimké’s abolitionist beliefs were inspired by a trip to Philadelphia with her father in which she encountered this religious group. Also known as the “Society of Friends,” they were known for their relatively liberal views on slavery and women’s equality.

This newspaper published “Letters on the Equality of the Sexes” in the same year it announced that it would “redeem woman as well as man from a servile to an equal condition,” adding abolition to its initial purpose. It was founded by William Lloyd Garrison.
Name this city, the setting of the play Hello and Goodbye. In another play set here, Zachariah prepares his brother Morris to impersonate him in a meeting with Ethel, his white pen-pal.
Port Elizabeth is a city in this country. This country is the setting of Blood Knot and Master Harold …and the Boys, two plays by Athol Fugard, an author of Afrikaner descent.
Fugard led a theater group called the Serpent Players in a 1963 production of The Cure, an adaptation of this author’s play The Mandrake.
Name this paper by George Akerlof that uses the example of a used car market to illustrate the problem of adverse selection.
The problem of adverse selection stems from asymmetry in this resource between two parties in a car purchase. Akerlof won a Nobel Prize for examining that asymmetry in this resource.

Adverse selection alters the distribution of people who choose to enter into a transaction. This related phenomenon occurs when people behave differently when risks are borne by other parties, such as flood insurance encouraging people to build houses in flood-prone areas.

answers: clearing the neighborhood of its orbit [accept descriptive answers where an object has removed other objects from its orbital path]
dwarf planet [do NOT accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this condition that, according to a recently formulated official definition, does not accompany orbiting of the sun and hydrostatic equilibrium for objects like Haumea.
Objects in hydrostatic equilibrium that orbit the Sun, but do not clear the neighborhood of their orbit, are known by this term, whose official definition was championed by Mike Brown.

Dwarf planet Ceres and potential dwarf planet Vesta are both members of this other class of objects. “Trojans” from this class occupy Lagrange points near Jupiter, but most of them live in a “belt” between Mars and Jupiter.

answers: Jeanne Antoinette Poisson, Madame de Pompadour [accept either underlined portion] <WA, ContHist>
parts: Give this word that also denotes the intellectual gatherings sponsored by many wealthy noblewomen during the 18th century, particularly in France.
Women in salons, particularly in Britain, were often referred to as having “blue” examples of these items. Elizabeth Montagu founded the original women’s “society” named for these.

This woman, a noted attendant of many salons, maintained a cordial relationship with her main romantic rival, Marie Leszczynska [lesh-CHIN-skah]. This patron of François Boucher [boo-shay] was a close friend of Voltaire.
Name this city where a man leads the John Reed Club and clashes with Buddy Nealson.
Chicago is the setting of American Hunger, the second section of this autobiographical novel.
Richard Wright, the author of Black Boy, also wrote this novel in which, despite the efforts of the communist lawyer Boris Max, Bigger Thomas is sentenced to death for killing Mary Dalton.
Name these substances that consist of insoluble particles suspended in a homogenous solution, exemplified by gels and aerosols.

The electric potential found at the slipping plane of colloidal double layers is calculated by this quantity. This quantity is often confused with the Stern potential, which is the electric potential at the surface of the double layer.

At a low zeta potential, attractive forces may overcome the repulsive forces within the colloid and begin this process. During this process, the dispersed particles in the colloid aggregate together to form flaky clusters.
Name this online retailer that recently entered the grocery business by purchasing Whole Foods.
Jeff Bezos, who founded Amazon, also founded this aerospace company that operates the New Shepard reusable launch vehicle. This company conducts test flights from a facility near Van Horn, Texas.
Since 2013, this publication has been owned by Jeff Bezos. This publication’s associate editors include Bob Woodward, who has worked at it since 1971.
At Samos, priests carried out hierogamy rituals representing the union of these two deities. One of these deities got extremely jealous at the other over an affair with Europa.

Among the Sumerians, a hierogamy was carried out by the chief priestess of this deity and the king of the city-state. You can give this deity’s name or that of the Assyro-Babylonian counterpart, who journeyed to the underworld to rescue Tammuz.

The Bible denounces Canaanite priests for conducting a hierogamy representing intercourse between El and this goddess. In related traditions, this goddess is the consort of Ba’al, or even Yahweh in some stories.

answers: paste [do not accept or prompt on anything else, since the story is titled “Paste”] <WA, Short>
parts: Name this story, in which Mathilde [muh-teeld] is forced to take on housework for ten years in order to pay off a debt incurred due to an accident at a ball.
“The Necklace” is by this French short story author, who also wrote “Mademoiselle Fifi.”

At the end of the story, a woman speculates that the original necklace that Mathilde borrowed was actually an imitation made of this material. Henry James titled a short story intended as a reversal of “The Necklace” after this material.

answers: Plutarch [or Ploutarchos] (the work is Parallel Lives)
parts: This author inserted an anecdote about a broken rope into his account of the failed coup of Cylon, which is found in a work that pairs biographies of Greeks and Romans.

Several authors write that this founder of Lydia’s Mernad dynasty decided to kill King Candaules [can-“DOW”-leez] and seize the throne after he got the hots for the king’s wife Tudo. He shares his name with a shepherd mentioned in Plato’s Republic.
This Roman emperor is recorded as lamenting “What an artist dies in me” before having his courier kill him during a coup. He probably didn’t actually play the fiddle while Rome burned.

answers: The Rape of Europa [or The Abduction of Europa] <EX, Painting>
parts: Two Titian paintings showing this mythological figure with a surprised face depict her with an aging maid and Eros, respectively. Rembrandt used his mistress Geertje Dircx [HAIR-chuh DIRKS] as a model for a painting of this woman with her arm outstretched in bed.

Titian’s final painting, which was completed by Palma the Younger, shows a depiction of this scene with the Virgin Mary and Nicodemus. In this scene, the Virgin Mary cradles the body of the dead Christ.
This Titian painting can be seen at the back of Diego Velázquez’s Las Hilanderas. This painting shows a woman waving a pink garment in the air while clinging onto the horn of a cow in the water.
This philosopher stated “here is one hand” as part of the title argument from his paper “Proof of an External World.”
This philosopher was unsure whether the world existed, but he at least proved that he himself existed with the phrase “I think, therefore I am” and proceeded from there with induction.

This philosopher called knowledge of the external world “sensitive knowledge” and said that it is different enough from “knowledge of appearances” to conclude that the world exists. This thinker’s conception of abstract ideas is attacked in another philosopher’s Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge.

answers: MOSFETs [or metal-oxide semiconductor field effect transistor; prompt on field-effect transistors and FETs]
parts: Name this type of transistor that has an insulating gate, which is separate from its source and drain.

MOSFETs can be composed of either p or n type semiconductors. The two types are differentiated based on whether or not they have larger concentrations of these negative charge carriers as opposed to holes, which are locations in the lattice where these particles are absent.
To form p-type and n-type semiconductors, the semiconductors must have foreign impurities introduced into their lattice, a process known by this name.

answers: Kyrgyzstan [or Kyrgyz Republic; or Kirghiz Respublikasi]
parts: Name this country where the US maintained an air base at Manas from 2001 to 2004.
The air base in Kyrgyzstan was built as part of the war in Afghanistan against this Islamic fundamentalist organization, which ran Afghanistan from 1996 to 2001. Their name means “students.”

This other country spent millions of dollars in the 2000s renovating Central Asian airbases to expand its military presence. This country lost a 1962 war with its northern neighbor along the McMahon [mac-MAN] line.

answers: “Ode on Indolence” [accept “The Indolence Ode”] (the poems in the first part are “Ode to Psyche” and “Ode to a Nightingale”) <WA, Poetry>
parts: Name this author, who opened another poem by stating “My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains / My sense, as though hemlock had I drunk.”
Another of Keats’s odes is inspired by a “Grecian” example of these objects lying in a forest.

This ode by Keats compares three passing figures in “white robes” and “placid sandals” to “figures on a marble urn,” and eventually commands them to “Vanish, ye phantoms!” This ode asks “How is it, shadows, that I knew ye not?”
Name this composer whose other chamber music includes several sets of Tafelmusik, or music meant to accompany a meal. This non-Handel composer created a “Water Music” suite depicting various deities.

Telemann was the godfather of a composer with this last name who succeeded him as Kapellmeister, and who wrote a noted Fantasia in F-sharp minor and Solfeggietto in C minor. That composer was often called the “Hamburg” man of this surname, to distinguish him from the “London” one.

Telemann’s concerto for this instrument is the oldest one still played in this instrument’s standard repertoire. Paul Hindemith played this string instrument, which is sized between a violin and a cello.

answers: walking around [or circumambulate; or circle it; accept equivalents] <VC, Rel>
parts: Name this fierce, invincible aspect of Parvati whose namesake puja is sometimes called Dashain [dah-shah-een]. This goddess rides a tiger and carries weapons with her ten arms.
Another common aspect of puja is this sort of offering, in which some food is shared with the relevant god and then consumed by worshippers.
In the ritual of parikrama, people do this to a sacred relic or religious site. Muslims on hajj do this counter-clockwise seven times to the Kaaba in the ritual of tawaf. A description is acceptable.
Name this term for compounds that conduct signals between neurons, such as serotonin, glutamate, and dopamine.
Loewi’s “vagusstoff” was this neurotransmitter, which is recognized by muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. It is broken down in the synaptic cleft by a namesake “esterase” enzyme.
The M1 and M3 classes of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors are Gq [G-Q] proteins, meaning they activate this enzyme to break down PIP2 [P-I-P-two] into IP3 [I-P-three] and DAG [dag].
